description: Nari (also known as Narfi) is a tragic figure in Norse mythology, one of two sons born to the trickster god Loki and his wife Sigyn. Nari's fate is inextricably bound to his father's punishment following the death of Baldr - the most beloved of the gods. When Loki's role in Baldr's death was discovered and he was finally captured after fleeing the gods' wrath, the Aesir enacted a terrible vengeance. According to the Prose Edda, the gods transformed Nari's brother Vali into a wolf, who then tore Nari to pieces. The gods then used Nari's entrails as chains to bind Loki to three rocks in a cave beneath the earth, where the serpent Skadi placed above him drips venom onto his face until Ragnarok. Nari's story represents the innocent who suffer for the sins of their parents, a theme that resonates across world mythology. His transformed entrails becoming unbreakable bonds symbolizes how family ties can become instruments of punishment and how the consequences of one's actions ripple through generations.

sections.origins: Nari appears in the Prose Edda (Gylfaginning and Skaldskaparmal), compiled by Snorri Sturluson in the 13th century from earlier oral traditions. His name may derive from Old Norse 'nar' meaning 'corpse' or be related to 'nari' meaning 'narrow' - both potentially foreshadowing his tragic fate. Some scholars distinguish between Nari and Narfi as two separate figures, with Narfi appearing in some genealogies as the father of Nott (Night), while others treat them as the same character. The binding of Loki myth, in which Nari plays his crucial role, appears to be an ancient narrative explaining why earthquakes occur (Loki writhing in his bonds) and connecting to the broader Ragnarok cycle. The myth may preserve elements of Indo-European traditions about divine punishment and the binding of chaotic forces.
sections.attributes: Nari is characterized primarily by his role as an innocent victim and instrument of divine justice. Unlike his monstrous half-siblings (Fenrir, Jormungandr, Hel) born from Loki's union with the giantess Angrboda, Nari and his brother Vali were born from Loki's legitimate marriage to Sigyn, making them fully divine Aesir. This makes his fate all the more poignant - he is not a monster to be bound but an innocent child sacrificed to bind his father. His entrails, transformed into unbreakable fetters, become symbolically charged: family bonds twisted into chains, the father's sins becoming the son's destruction. Nari represents the collateral damage of divine conflicts, the innocent caught between cosmic forces.
sections.significance: Nari's significance in Norse mythology lies in several dimensions. First, his story completes the cycle of Loki's punishment, demonstrating that the trickster's actions have consequences not only for himself but for his innocent children. Second, Nari exemplifies the tragic theme of children suffering for parental sins - a motif appearing across mythologies from Oedipus's children to the biblical sins visited upon generations. Third, the transformation of his entrails into unbreakable bonds presents a powerful image of how family connections can become instruments of suffering. Fourth, his story connects to the Ragnarok cycle: Loki remains bound until the twilight of the gods, when he will break free (presumably when Nari's entrails finally decay), suggesting that even the most terrible bonds eventually dissolve. Nari thus embodies themes of innocence, suffering, family, and cosmic inevitability.
sections.culturalImpact: While Nari is not among the most prominent Norse mythological figures, his story has influenced understanding of Norse conceptions of fate, family, and divine justice. His tale appears in modern retellings and adaptations of Norse mythology, often highlighted for its pathos and moral complexity. The image of Loki bound with his son's entrails has become an iconic scene in Norse mythological art and literature. Contemporary interpretations often focus on the injustice of Nari's fate, using his story to explore themes of innocent victims, transgenerational trauma, and the moral ambiguity of the Norse gods. In psychological interpretations, Nari represents aspects of self destroyed or sacrificed due to the shadow (represented by Loki's trickster nature). His brief but powerful presence in the mythology speaks to the Norse awareness that cosmic dramas have human costs.
